Dr Shereen Rachel Varghese, 
Department of Microbiology, 
Christian Medical College & 
Hospital, Ludhiana 141008, India
shereenrv@gmail.com

y.e.li@bham.ac.uk

Microbiology testing capacity and antimicrobial drug 
resistance in surgical-site infections: a post-hoc, prospective, 
secondary analysis of the FALCON randomised trial in 
seven low-income and middle-income countries
NIHR Global Health Research Unit on Global Surgery*

Summary
Background Surgical-site infection (SSI) is one of the most common health-care-associated infections, substantially 
contributing to antibiotic use. Targeted antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent SSIs and effective treatment are crucial to 
controlling antimicrobial resistance (AMR). This study aimed to describe the testing capacity and multidrug 
resistance (MDR) of SSI microorganisms in low-income and middle-income countries (LMICs).

Methods This analysis included patients undergoing abdominal surgery in seven LMICs (Benin, Ghana, India, 
Mexico, Nigeria, Rwanda, and South Africa) as part of the FALCON randomised controlled trial. Wound swabs were 
collected from patients diagnosed with SSI, as per US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) definition. 
Data on microorganism species and MDR, as per CDC and European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control 
definitions, were analysed alongside hospital-level data on local microbiological practices. An adjusted analysis was 
performed to identify perioperative factors associated with MDR. Testing capacity was assessed by the completion of 
swab testing in positively diagnosed SSIs.

Findings Between Dec 10, 2018, and Sept 7, 2020, 5788 patients were recruited to the FALCON trial. 1163 patients were 
diagnosed with an SSI, of whom 905 (77·8%) received prophylactic antibiotics before surgery. In patients with SSIs, 
935 of 1163 (80·4%) did not have a wound swab; 195 were from hospitals not performing swabs (15 hospitals) and 
740 were from hospitals with capacity but no swab performed (35 hospitals). Of 228 patients swabbed, 200 (88·5%) 
had microorganisms detected. Escherichia coli (89 of 200, 37·9%) was the most common microorganism and 
116 of 200 (58·0%) patients were not covered by the perioperative prophylactic antibiotic. MDR was found in 
102 of 147 (69·4%) patients for whom data were available to determine MDR status. Adjusted analysis found that 
appropriate prophylactic antibiotic coverage (adjusted odds ratio 0·43, 95% CI 0·19–0·96) and regular availability of 
infection control teams (0·32, 0·11–0·93) were associated with a significant reduction in MDR.

Interpretation Targeted perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis during contaminated abdominal surgery is insufficient in 
LMICs, with very few SSI organisms undergoing formal diagnosis. Expansion of testing capacity, development of 
local guidelines, and implementation of infection control teams could support the prevention of SSI through directed 
antibiotic prophylaxis, subsequently reducing the burden of MDR.
Funding National Institute for Health and Care Research.

Copyright © 2024 The Author(s). Published by Elsevier Ltd. This is an Open Access article under the CC BY 4.0 
license.

Introduction
Surgical-site infection (SSI) is one of the most 
common health-care-associated infections globally 
and the most frequent postoperative complication,1,2 
affecting 15–25% of all patients undergoing abdominal 
surgery.2–4 Patients from low-income countries are 
disproportionately affected (23·2%) compared with 
those in middle-income (14·0%) and high-income 
countries (9·4%).2 Because SSIs typically require 
antibiotic treatment, the development of SSIs increases 
the need for additional antibiotic use. Therefore, SSI 
prevention and targeted antibiotics are key in controlling 
antimicrobial resistance (AMR). WHO guidelines

strongly recommend prophylactic antibiotics to prevent 
SSIs.5 However, inappropriate use is common. In the 
past two decades, the biggest growth in antibiotic use 
has been in low-income and middle-income countries 
(LMICs),6 and a 165% rise in the use of second-line 
antibiotics—which are normally reserved for when 
first-line antibiotics fail— has been seen in these 
settings.7 Antimicrobial-resistant SSIs have a higher 
incidence in low-income countries (35·9%) compared 
with that in middle-income (19·8%) and high-income 
countries (16·6%).2 WHO has declared that AMR is in 
the top ten global public health threats facing humanity,8 
and the Africa Centres for Disease Control and

Prevention identified AMR as an urgent public health 
threat in 2023.9 The Fleming Fund (Department of 
Health and Social Care, UK)10,11 aims to help LMICs gain 
knowledge and control of AMR by 2040. Management of 
SSIs, controlling antibiotic use, timely identification of 
causative organisms, and reducing AMR will require 
system-wide approaches that target multiple factors 
(appendix 3 p 14).

Although the development of AMR is a natural 
phenomenon, the inappropriate use of antimicrobial 
drugs and poor infection prevention and control practices 
contribute to the emergence of and further spread 
of AMR alongside an accelerated progression into 
multidrug resistance (MDR).12 One systematic analysis 
of 
the 
burden 
of 
AMR 
found 
an 
estimated 
4·95 million deaths associated with bacterial AMR 
in the year 2019, with sub-Saharan Africa observing the 
highest death rate of 27·3 per 100 deaths.13 As well as 
increased mortality and morbidity, AMR is associated 
with an increased length of hospital stay, difficulty 
treating infections, high health-care costs, and risk of 
catastrophic health expenditure for patients, particularly 
in LMICs.12,14

This study aimed to analyse the antibiotic susceptibility 
of bacteria in wound swabs of patients who developed an 
SSI and the microbiology testing capacity and 
antimicrobial practices of the facilities these patients

were admitted to during the FALCON randomised 
controlled 
trial 
(a 
2 × 2 
factorial 
trial 
testing 
two interventions aimed at the prevention of SSIs).

Methods
Study design
This study was a post-hoc prospective secondary analysis 
of a randomised controlled trial, with a protocol designed 
before data analysis.15 This study is reported according to 
the STROBE statement (appendix 3 pp 16–20).16 The 
FALCON 
trial 
evaluated 
the 
effectiveness 
of 
two interventions (2% alcoholic chlorhexidine and 
triclosan-coated sutures) recommended by WHO to 
reduce SSIs after abdominal surgery.4,5,15 Patient 
identification, recruitment to the trial, and outcomes 
have been comprehensively described in the FALCON 
trial protocol and primary analysis (appendix 3 
pp 21–71).4,15 Here, we provide a summary of the main 
trial.

The FALCON trial recruited all eligible, consecutive 
patients undergoing abdominal surgery with an incision 
of 5 cm or greater. The trial was undertaken in 
54 hospitals in seven countries (Benin, Ghana, India, 
Mexico, Nigeria, Rwanda, and South Africa). Patients 
were randomly assigned by a 2 × 2 factorial design to 
receive 
either 
2% 
alcoholic 
chlorhexidine 
or 
10% aqueous povidone–iodine skin preparation, and

Evidence before this study
Surgical-site infection (SSI) remains the most common 
postoperative complication and is associated with substantial 
morbidity and mortality, particularly in low-resource settings. 
A search was conducted to identify studies of SSI that 
described microorganisms and antibiotic resistance from low-
income and middle-income countries (LMICs), published 
between Jan 1, 2000, and Feb 16, 2023, with no restrictions on 
the language of publication. We used the search terms “surgical 
site infection”, “abdominal surgery”, and “microorganism” or 
“antibiotic resistance” or any equivalents to these on the 
MEDLINE, Embase, and Cochrane Library databases. This search 
identified 153 full-text articles. We found no multicentre 
studies reporting SSI microorganisms or microbiology testing 
capacity in hospitals from LMICs. One report described 
antimicrobial resistance patterns in SSI from a single hospital 
in Kenya, and an interventional cohort study described 
antibiotic stewardship for SSI from India. The remaining 
evidence was largely single-centre or single-country 
observational studies, commentary, and reviews, or was from 
high-income settings.

Added value of this study
This study provides prospective data from seven LMICs on 
antimicrobial use in SSIs, microorganism testing capacity, and 
antimicrobial resistance patterns, as a secondary analysis of the

FALCON randomised controlled trial. The infrastructure of a 
major randomised trial allowed for a multicentre analysis that 
substantially adds to the current evidence from single-centre 
studies. We found that whole-system weaknesses are common 
in the identification and prevention of multidrug 
resistance (MDR) in hospitals where surgery is performed in 
LMICs. Expansion of testing capacity, development of local 
guidelines, and implementation of infection control teams will 
support the prevention of SSI, the reduction of inappropriate 
antibiotic use, and the reduction of propagation of MDR 
through directed antibiotic prophylaxis.

Implications of all the available evidence
MDR in SSIs and limited microbial capacity are substantial 
problems in LMICs, probably affecting most hospitals where 
surgery is performed. When infections do occur, testing capacity 
is low, turnaround time is long, and MDR is high. Thus, 
undirected prophylactic antibiotic use before surgery that is 
ineffective is common. This study has identified the pressing 
need for an expansion of testing strategies, development of 
local antimicrobial guidelines (especially context-specific 
prophylaxis guidance), and dedicated infection control teams 
to tackle infection prevention and antimicrobial drug use. 
Targeted prophylactic antibiotic prevention of SSIs is central to 
improved patient care and will be likely to have positive effects 
beyond surgery alone.

either triclosan-coated sutures or non-coated sutures. 
Patients were stratified by level of intraoperative 
contamination (appendix 3 p 2). Those undergoing 
clean operations (in which the gastrointestinal tract is 
not entered) were excluded. Patient demographics (age, 
sex, diabetes status, smoking status, HIV status, and 
American Society of Anesthesiologists [ASA] grade), 
perioperative factors (including urgency, contamination, 
and whether prophylactic antibiotics were given), and 
30-day postoperative follow-up data (including SSI and 
microbiology swab data) were prospectively collected. 
Patients provided written informed consent, which 
included the use of collected data in all secondary 
analyses. Approval for this analysis was given by 
the FALCON trial management group. FALCON was 
approved by the University of Birmingham Research 
Ethics Committee (ERN_180230). Ethics and regulatory 
approvals in each participating country were sought in 
line with regional or national regulations, or both. The 
trial was prospectively registered at ClinicalTrials.gov, 
NCT03700749.

Microbiology analysis
Patients with a diagnosis of SSI (as per the US Centers 
for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] criteria for 
SSI)17 were included in this analysis. This analysis is 
based on the presumption that all patients who have a 
confirmed SSI diagnosis should have a wound swab 
taken for microbiological analysis so that the infective 
organisms can be identified, and microorganism 
antibiotic susceptibility testing can be performed to 
enable directed antibiotic use (thereby reducing use of 
empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics). However, there 
was no stipulation in the trial protocol that patients must 
have wound swabs. The full patient inclusion and 
exclusion criteria of the FALCON trial are presented in 
appendix 3 (p 3). The decision to swab an SSI was 
presumptively determined by local clinical practices, 
patient’s choice, or patient’s ability to afford the test, 
although data on reasoning for decisions were not 
collected. 
Microbiological 
cultures 
and 
antibiotic 
susceptibility and AMR testing were carried out in local 
microbiology facilities. Susceptibility was defined 
according to the Clinical and Laboratory Standards 
Institute and the European Committee on Antimicrobial 
Susceptibility Testing guidelines.18 Non-bacterial isolates, 
such as yeast, were excluded from analysis. The 
microbiology results were categorised according to: 
MDR profiles of isolates; number of isolates in swabs; 
and whether isolates were endogenous to gut flora, skin 
flora, or both. MDR categorisation was performed based 
on these data. Analyses were performed on MDR and 
non-MDR isolates, whether swabs grew monomicrobial 
or polymicrobial cultures, and whether isolated 
pathogens were endogenous to gut and skin flora. These 
variables were analysed against patient demographics, 
operative factors, and patient outcomes. Duplicate data

were removed and there were no allowances for 
multiplicity for this analysis.

MDR was defined as “acquired non-susceptibility to at 
least one agent in three or more antimicrobial categories”19 
and was calculated according to the European Centre for 
Disease Prevention and Control and CDC criteria. If there 
were not enough antibiotic categories tested, the 
organisms were categorised as being unknown due to 
insufficient data. Further subcategorisation of MDR 
organisms as extremely drug resistant or pan-drug 
resistant was not done. If a wound swab contained more

Figure 1: Patients from the FALCON randomised controlled trial included in these analyses
A complete analysis of patients with and without SSIs has been previously reported.4 This study focuses on 
patients with SSIs and microbiology testing of wound swabs. SSI=surgical-site infection.

than one microorganism within a mixture of isolates, it 
was dichotomised and classified as MDR if there was 
one or more MDR isolate in the swab. When wound swab 
testing was insufficient to reliably classify the bacterial 
isolates, they were excluded from the MDR analysis. 
The hospital-level survey also addressed MDR by 
requesting information on whether participating hospitals 
routinely screened for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus 
aureus, extended spectrum beta-lactamase, carbapenem-
resistant Enterobacteriaceae, and vancomycin-resistant 
Enterococcus.

Outcomes and procedures
The primary outcomes were the incidence of MDR 
microorganisms in abdominal SSI swabs and the patient, 
operative, or system-wide factors associated with these 
MDR SSIs. Secondary outcomes, compared across 
countries and levels of intraoperative contamination, 
were: microbiological testing practices and capacity 
across different types of health-care facility; characteristics 
of isolated microorganisms, including the genus and 
species, Gram stain, origin, and the association with the 
level of intraoperative contamination; and patterns of 
antibiotic susceptibility and resistance in microorganisms 
isolated from wound swabs.

Resistance was calculated as a percentage, with a 
higher rate of susceptibility or resistance if the result was 
closer or equal to 100%, and a lower rate of susceptibility 
and resistance if closer or equal to 0%: antibiotic 
resistance=number of times microorganism is resistant 
to antibiotics / total number of microorganisms × 100%.

A hospital-level survey was developed to capture key 
datapoints not available from the FALCON data, to 
facilitate a more complete descriptive analysis. This 
survey was conducted after the completion of the trial. To 
determine the key datapoints, five international forums 
were held between January, 2021, and May, 2022. These 
were attended by 18 experts, consisting of microbiologists 
and surgeons from seven LMIC hospitals. Discussion 
focused on gaps in knowledge, high-utility data, key 
comparators, and global standards. These datapoints 
were then iteratively codeveloped and refined into a 
hospital-level survey (appendix 3 pp 27–33) by a core 
group of four microbiologists and the central research 
team. Infrastructure and processing resources identified 
as core service components to ensure high-quality 
microbiology care were captured. These components 
included wound swabbing procedures, susceptibility 
testing definitions, culture media, transport practices, 
turnover 
times, 
standard 
antibiotic 
prophylaxis, 
susceptibility 
testing 
antibiotics, 
AMR 
pathogen 
screening, antimicrobial surveillance, and availability of 
infection control teams. This assessment of local capacity 
and surveillance systems provided an international, real-
world snapshot of microbiological capacity.

The survey was sent to all participating hospitals with 
testing capacity in May, 2022. Any member of staff, either

Patients with SSI, included in the analyses of this 
study

Patients without 
SSI, excluded from 
the analyses of this 
study (n=4120)

new to this analysis study or who had originally taken 
part in the FALCON trial, was invited to participate, 
although only one response was required per hospital. A 
secure online link was made available. Respondents 
entered data directly onto the REDCap web application,20 
based in the secure servers in the University of 
Birmingham (Birmingham, UK). For continuous data, a 
mean average was calculated.

Entries that were missing SSI status, which was the 
primary outcome from the FALCON trial, were excluded 
in the same manner as the original analysis.4 Missing 
datapoints from the hospital-level survey were promptly 
queried

Statistical analysis
Categorical 
outcomes 
were 
summarised 
using 
frequencies and proportions and continuous outcomes 
were summarised using medians and IQRs. The primary 
analysis was modelled using mixed-effects multivariable 
logistic regression adjusting for ASA grade, timing of 
surgery (emergency or elective), and intraoperative 
contamination. Hospital was included as a random 
effect. Adjusted odds ratios, 95% CIs, and p values from 
two-sided tests are presented for the multivariable 
analysis of the primary outcome and for point estimates 
of results. These factors were chosen because they were 
inherent properties of operative procedures and known 
to have an effect on the incidence of SSIs, and hence 
were also most likely to affect MDR.

Similar summary statistics for the primary outcome 
are also presented across the following groups: specific 
microorganisms and operative factors, whether patients 
underwent clean-contaminated versus contaminated or 
dirty surgery, and across different countries. p<0·05 was 
considered to indicate statistical significance. Analyses 
were performed with Stata SE version 16.1.

Role of the funding source
The funder of the study had no role in study design, data 
collection, data analysis, data interpretation, or writing of 
the report.

Results
Between Dec 10, 2018, and Sept 7, 2020, 5788 patients 
were recruited to the FALCON trial. Because the primary 
trial has been reported and compared patients with and 
without SSIs,4 this current analysis focuses on patients 
with SSI only, and 4120 patients without SSIs were 
excluded (figure 1). Overall, 1163 of 5284 patients (22·0% 
[95% CI 20·9–23·2]) at 50 hospitals were diagnosed with 
an SSI in the FALCON trial. Of these patients with SSIs, 
228 of 1163 (19·6% [17·4–22·0]) had a wound swab taken 
(table). 935 (80·4%) patients did not have a swab taken, 
among whom 195 (20·9% [18·3–23·6]) were from 
hospitals (n=15) that did not have capacity to carry out 
microbiological analysis and 740 (79·1% [76·4–81·7]) were 
from hospitals (n=35) that had capacity but did not swab

the SSI wound (appendix 3 p 4). The demographics of 
patients who had a swab taken versus those who did not 
are shown in the table. The 35 hospitals with testing 
capacity were based in all seven countries (Benin, India, 
Mexico, Nigeria, Ghana, Rwanda, and South Africa). 
Missing datapoints from the original dataset in this 
current analysis amounted to less than 0·8% of the total 
datapoints. There were no missing datapoints in the 
hospital-level survey.

200 (87·7%) patients had a wound swab that cultured a 
microorganism. 235 microorganisms were detected,

study

because 35 swabs grew more than one microorganism, 
and 30 different microorganisms were reported. 
Compared with patients with no swab or no 
microorganism grown (n=28), patients with a positive 
microorganism identified (n=200) tended to be from 
hospitals situated in low-income countries, and tended 
to be younger than 18 years, male, ASA grade 3–5, 
undergoing 
emergency 
surgery, 
undergoing 
a 
contaminated or dirty procedure, and to have benign 
surgical pathology (appendix 3 p 5). Stomas were more 
common in the patients with a positive swab, which 
might 
reflect 
an 
increased 
number of 
heavily 
contaminated surgical procedures that prevented safe 
bowel anastomosis, or the ongoing presence of an 
ostomy that diverted effluence to the abdominal wall, 
which increased the risk of SSIs (appendix 3 p 5). 
Patients with an SSI who had a swab taken also appeared 
to be more symptomatic, with higher rates of tenderness, 
swelling, and redness (appendix 3 p 6).

Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, was by 
far the most common prophylactic antibiotic given to 
patients with SSIs. It was given alone in 288 patients 
(24·8% [95% CI 22·3–27·3]) and in combination with 
metronidazole in 188 patients (17·6% [14·1–18·4]; table 1, 
appendix 3 p 7). Of the 235 microorganisms detected, 
77 (32·8% [26·8–39·2]) were susceptible to the 
prophylactic antibiotic given (appendix 3 p 8).

Escherichia coli was the most common species 
identified (89 of 235; 37·9% [95% CI 31·6–44·4]), 
followed by Klebsiella spp. (33 of 235; 14·0% [9·9–19·2], 
appendix 3 p 8). Gram-negative bacteria constituted 
179 of 235 (76·2% [70·2–81·5]) and four of 235 
(1·7% [0·5–4·3]) were yeasts. Most organisms grown 
were 
primarily 
of 
gut 
origin 
(199 
of 
235; 
84·7% [79·4–89·0]; 26 of 235 (11·0% [7·4–15·8]) were 
primarily of skin origin and ten (4·3% [2·1–7·7]) could 
be of either origin (appendix 3 pp 9, 15). Standard 
microbiological analysis practice in hospitals in the 
study is presented in figure 2.

For many wound swabs, details on the reported 
microorganisms were incomplete and often not subjected 
to extensive antibiotic susceptibility testing. For example, 
in several cases, the specific species was not reported and 
only the genus was identified. The results reported here 
reflect the level of granularity available from the 
participating hospitals.

MDR was identified in 120 of 235 (51·1% [95% CI 
44·5–57·6]) microorganisms. 56 of 235 (23·8%

[18·5–29·8]) did not have MDR and 59 of 235 
(25·1% [19·7–31·2]) did not have sufficient testing data 
to classify the microorganism (appendix 3 pp 8, 15). 
MDR was more commonly detected when the isolated 
micro­organism was not susceptible to the preoperative 
prophylactic antibiotic given. There was sufficient 
prophylactic antibiotic coverage in 44·6% (31·3–58·5) 
of the non-MDR microorganisms, whereas in the 
MDR microorganisms, there was sufficient coverage 
in 26·7% (19·0–35·5; appendix p 8). In adjusted analysis, 
sufficient coverage for microorganisms by prophylactic 
antibiotics and regular availability of infection control 
teams were significantly associated with reduced MDR 
(figure 3).

Turnaround time (from sending the wound swab to 
receiving the results) was reported to be 48 h or longer in 
149 of 200 cases (74·5% [95% CI 67·9–80·4]) and 72 h or 
longer in 75 of 200 cases (37·5% [30·8–44·6], figure 2). 
Analytical profile index, a classification of bacteria based 
on biochemical tests that allows fast identification, was 
only available for 29 of 200 cases (14·5% [9·9–20·2], 
figure 2).

There were notable differences in the composition 
of MDR microorganisms in different circumstances. 
E coli and S aureus were the most common MDR 
microorganisms 
in 
clean-contaminated 
surgeries, 
whereas E coli and Klebsiella spp. were the most common 
MDR microorganisms in contaminated or dirty 
surgeries (appendix 3 pp 2, 12). Differences were also

seen between countries. In Nigeria, Klebsiella spp. and 
S aureus were the most common MDR microorganisms, 
whereas in India and Ghana, E coli was the most 
common (appendix 3 p 13).

The antibiotics most widely tested for susceptibility 
were gentamicin (17·8% susceptibility), third-generation 
cephalosporins (16·6% susceptibility), second-generation 
fluroquinolones 
(11·2% 
susceptibility), 
and 
anti­
pseudomonal 
penicillin 
(14·0% 
susceptibility). 
Chloram­phenicol had the highest overall susceptibility 
of 24·2%. Of those tested, microorganisms had 
no susceptibility (0%) to third-generation and fourth-
generation fluroquinolones, isoniazid, clindamycin, 
metronidazole, 
flucloxacillin 
and 
quinupristin–
dalfopristin (figure 4A, appendix 3 p 10).

The antibiotics with highest levels of resistance, 
proportionally, were second-generation cephalosporins 
(77·4% resistance), third-generation cephalosporins 
(48·1% resistance), penicillin (43·1% resistance), and 
second-generation fluoroquinolones (42·2% resistance; 
figure 4B, appendix 3 p 11). The most prescribed surgical 
prophylaxis drug was ceftriaxone, a third-generation 
cephalosporin.

Discussion
This study aimed to carry out a post-hoc analysis of SSI 
wound swabs from a randomised controlled trial. The 
two key findings were high levels of MDR, and low 
capacity for microbiological testing alongside an absence

of infection control teams. Around half of hospitals that 
performed microbiological testing had regular reviews by 
infection control teams and more than a third had no 
reviews by infection control teams. Despite widespread 
use of prophylactic antibiotics, they were frequently 
ineffective, which is associated with a substantial increase 
in MDR organisms. Data are scarce from LMICs and the 
little evidence that has emerged is concerning. A study 
from Uganda of 83 patients with SSIs found that 
86·0% of aerobic bacteria isolated were MDR.21,22 A study 
from Benin found that 41·2% of the bacteria isolated 
from SSIs were MDR.23 A 2024 meta-analysis of 
59 
articles 
identified 
that 
the 
top 
three 
SSI 
microorganisms had very high levels of AMR 
(48% methicillin resistance in S aureus, 64% in E coli, and 
up to 85% in Klebsiella pneumoniae).24 AMR is particularly 
challenging in LMICs with a scarcity of microbial data, 
lower levels of awareness, and widespread lack of local 
guidelines.

The findings in this study sit within and expand upon 
the Mapping Antimicrobial Resistance and Antimicrobial 
Use Partnership9 involving 14 African countries, which 
identified that only 1·3% of laboratories across the 
14 countries perform bacteriological testing and 
12 of the 14 countries have a drug resistance index at 
least twice the benchmark of 25%.25 Poor access to 
microbiology diagnostics and overuse and misuse of 
antimicrobials are major drivers in the development 
of MDR.8,26

Optimising targeted antibiotic treatment requires a full 
complement of microbiology services, stewardship, 
education, and appropriate antimicrobial use. Substantial 
investment is required in infrastructure and workforce, 
which poses significant challenges in resource-limited 
settings.27,28 When patients pay for their own health care, 
diagnosis and treatment of SSI can be beyond the means 
of public health-care systems and can lead to catastrophic 
expenditure for patients and families.3,14,29 Worsening 
MDR could outpace efforts to expand microbiological 
infrastructure and services and lead to extensive 
untreatable SSIs.26

A strength of this study is its scope, reporting data 
across 35 hospitals from seven LMICs, providing a 
comprehensive overview of the testing capacity and 
MDR on the front line. This study is based on high-
quality, prospectively collected data from dedicated 
research teams as part of a randomised controlled trial, 
making this a generalisable snapshot of the current 
environment. A limitation of this study was that, 
although it was included in the FALCON protocol 
written before the trial, this was a post-hoc prospective 
secondary analysis of a randomised controlled trial, and 
microorganism analysis was not the primary outcome of 
the FALCON trial. Other limitations include: we were 
unable to report the exact reason that swabs were or 
were not taken; due to current practices in hospitals, we 
were unable to capture wound swab data on MDR and

microorganisms in every SSI; due to limited testing 
capacity, a substantial number of microorganisms could 
not be classified as MDR or not MDR by the accepted 
definition; we could not specify the cases where SSI was 
prevented by antibiotics, although we suspect this was 
proportionately very low because we found that antibiotic 
use was almost entirely non-targeted; detailed data on 
specific factors that influenced prophylactic antibiotic 
use were not available (based on national or regional 
guidelines, the patient’s choice, or intraoperative 
findings); and granular information on the laboratory 
testing conditions, quality controls, culture mediums, 
and transport was beyond the scope of this study and 
requires a larger, separate study, designed specifically to 
answer these questions. The hospital-level survey was 
not intended to be exhaustive, because it was intended to 
support the secondary analysis from the primary trial. It 
was intended to identify unmet needs and areas for 
focusing future research.

To prevent worsening MDR, goal-directed future 
research and initiatives are needed. First, prevention 
efforts are essential. These will reduce overall antibiotic 
consumption and can be cost-effective and implemented 
in all settings, even where resources are limited. For 
example, the ChEETAh randomised controlled trial has 
shown that a change of gloves and instruments before 
wound closure significantly reduces SSI.30 Second, global 
mapping of local microorganism patterns by way of an 
active and responsive surveillance network will be key to 
effective, targeted antibiotic use. Third, evidence-based 
best practice must be implemented on the front line, 
facilitated by communication between departments, 
education of staff, and behavioural change through 
awareness and team building. Fourth, the effectiveness 
of a dedicated infection control team needs to be explored 
and a cost-effectiveness model is needed. Finally, when 
SSIs do occur, capacity for microorganism testing is 
crucial for targeted treatment instead of broad-spectrum 
antibiotic use. To achieve this targeted antibiotic 
treatment, effective, rapid, low-cost diagnostic tools are 
needed. Evidence-based prescribing on local microbial 
and resistance patterns should be the standard of care.

In conclusion, systemic weaknesses exist in the 
testing capacity and prevention of MDR in LMIC 
hospitals. These weaknesses are associated with non-
targeted antibiotic use and high levels of AMR. Future 
research should be directed towards development of 
guidelines, and implementation of infection control 
teams to educate staff and patients to reduce the burden 
of MDR SSIs.

Contributors
The role of all coauthors is shown in appendix 3 (pp 117–122). 
The writing group, which consisted of the microbiology expert group 
and the surgical expert group, contributed to conceptualisation, 
methodology, data curation, analysis, investigation, writing of the 
original draft, and review and editing, and have accessed and verified the 
data. EL (UK), SRV (India), and AB (UK) were responsible for the 
decision to submit the manuscript for publication.

Equitable partnership declaration
The authors of this paper have submitted an equitable partnership 
declaration (appendix 4). This statement allows researchers to describe 
how their work engages with researchers, communities, and 
environments in the countries of study. This statement is part of 
The Lancet Global Health’s broader goal to decolonise global health.

Declaration of interests
We declare no competing interests.

Data sharing
Data sharing requests will be considered by the writing group upon 
written request to the corresponding author.
